replies.body:
Hi Shes my Princess,

As mentioned before in other similar threads, most permabans are not the result of a single instance of negative behaviour.

I had a look through your account and in the last 12 months, you have received 5 (6 including this perma) punishments for negative behaviour. Every time you recieve a punishment, your account gets escalated and based on your record, you were on very thin ice already after 3 chat restrictions and 2 time bans. 

It was your behaviour as a whole that resulted in your permaban, though it was the reports by players in your last game that tipped you over the edge.

I would also like to note that the assumption that Riot has a list of god-level "no-no" terms is not entirely correct. The automated system is populated based on reports by other players and the community as a whole has deemed (through their reports) that some things are not acceptable.

Hope that gives you and others enough context!

>I would also like to note that the assumption that Riot has a list of god-level "no-no" terms is not entirely correct. The automated system is populated based on reports by other players and the community as a whole has deemed (through their reports) that some things are not acceptable.

So in other words, riot DOES have a list of god-level "no-no" words.

Whether determined by the "community as a whole" (which really means the community that reports people, lets not pretend that it's determined by EVERYONE, if that were the case, it'd be a vote in client as to whether saying something is ok or not) or not, it's still a list of words we can't say or we are likely to get banned.

It means that while Riot doesn't strictly have a list of keywords, those keywords will often prompt people to report. For a lot of people, saying "kys" is enough reason to straight away report someone, regardless of context or what else they say. So in that sense, yes there is a list of keywords that contribute to punishments, but it's not nearly that simple overall.

If you're being reported in the majority of your games, safe to say a majority (or at least very significant portion) of the community thinks that behaviour isn't ok. If you think a certain behaviour is ok, then don't report it, people can agree or disagree with their own reports same as you. Essentially, if you care about the behaviour being demonstrated, you'll vote on it, and if not, then you aren't who reports are for and they shouldn't affect you.

Seras, please just don't talk when you don't know what your talking about.

They have a bot that automatically bans people, meaning that the bot has a list of keywords.

>If you're being reported in the majority of your games, safe to say a majority (or at least very significant portion)

"Majority" being reported doesn't mean a majority is mad, it means a MINORITY is mad.

1 person reports you in every single game for example.

You have been reported by 11% of the people you encounter.

THIS IS NOT A MAJORITY.

except if someone is being reported and likely to receive a significant punishment from that game (i.e an actual restriction or ban as opposed to a mark on their history) then more than likely it's not just one or two people reporting them. I've seen people on boards who say "why did I get banned?" then we find out they are being reported by nearly everyone on their team (if not in the game) in pretty much all of their games.

If the behaviour is something mundane enough to take a while to warrant a punishment then sure it might be a minority per game, but if you're saying shit like "kys" then that's unlikely.

There is more to the system than just keywords. That players history is taken into account (do they get reported a lot), how many people reported them this game (was it just one salty person or was there a real reason), were there comments on the reports etc etc.

If it was only keywords then people who abused their teammates without swearing would never be punished, but they are. I never said there wasn't a list of keywords, because there is (it's just not generated by Riot, or at least not anymore), what I'm saying is that keywords aren't the only thing that get you punished.

>I've seen people on boards who say "why did I get banned?" then we find out they are being reported by nearly everyone on their team (if not in the game) in pretty much all of their games.

Where's the proof other then taking riot's word?

>If it was only keywords then people who abused their teammates without swearing would never be punished, but they are.

Burden of proof is here, says your talking out your ass.

Fact is i want you to prove it's not keywords, you can't, because it is.

If it's automated, it's looking for keywords, bot's can't determine context, now please shut up about shit you don't understand.

Where's the proof they are lying? If they were lying do you not think those people would call them out? Say something like "there's no way I was reported in that many games" or something? They don't, which would in most circumstances mean they know what they did, but were just trying to get out of responsibility.

Again, I never said keywords aren't involved, I said it wasn't *only* keywords. Besides your argument goes both ways, prove to me that it's only keywords that prompt bans. There are recorded cases here on boards where no swears were said, but in abusing a teammate someone still gets banned.

A simple yes or no bot can't determine context sure, but that's obvious. The automated system is designed to see patterns in behaviour, not just keywords, it learns those patterns from what players report. If x pattern is reported by 90% of players, chances are it's negative.

You're assuming I'm wrong because I don't have hard proof, while you also lack any hard proof to the contrary. 

If Riot lied about such things they'd get called out, like they do when something gets bungled with a 3rd party banned but compromised account. The fact that they don't says to me that those people know exactly what they did and how many games they are more than likely being reported in.

If the automated system only functioned on keywords you wouldn't see people not saying 'bad words' getting banned, and people who say 'bad words' but aren't abusive not getting banned. But hey, what do I know right?

Personally as a League player myself, I would have reported OP for using that phrase because it's something I don't want to see when I'm playing. More importantly, the players in that match had that same view regardless of "banter" context and felt the need to report OP for it.

While I can't comment on the exact details of how the automated system works (as in, the literal logic it uses), I can say that your interpretation of it is not quite right. It's not so much that the system scans games for words, but rather Player Reports, bring games for review. 

Had no one reported OP for saying "KYS", the system would not have actioned anything. It is because players in that match felt - even with so called "banter" context - that what OP said was unacceptable and reported it, that the system then took action. This is how it was intended to work - you, the players as a collective, decide what is acceptable or not. The idea is that the person(s) in the best position to make a judgement on behaviour, are the players in that specific game. 

I am by no means saying this is a perfect system - far from it - but definitely something that is continually being iterated and improved upon.

you must realise how out of hand the punishments are getting for chat. it was bad enough before but now you're accelerating it. who the fuck decided that using specific words skips chat restrictions? fresh accounts are receiving instant suspensions so your "past behaviour" bs doesn't actually apply for specific words. it seems someone realised you can make it appear like you're really cracking down on "toxicity" without actually doing anything more than you were before.

If the community's stance on such words differed from Riot's then it's entirely possible they would set a rule and put measures in place to prevent that behaviour beyond what the system does, but as it is they don't have to because the community has already prompted the automated system to do so.

People were trying to claim that Riot created a list of keywords that automatically triggered the automated system. I was only trying to explain that that isn't how it works.

But I also don't know if there are exceptions to that. I don't believe so, but it is possible that a manual connection was made for some things like kys or racial slurs. On the other hand, I don't think making that manual connection would have ever be necessary, since as a whole the community reports those things pretty consistently.

I disagree that there are better ways to punish chat related offenses, since the idea isn't to hide the behaviour it's to show why it's not okay and hopefully change it (i.e reform) and things like permanent chat restrictions don't accomplish that at all, though there is an argument that they *might* protect other players better (though also one that they would simply find other ways to be toxic).

I do agree that Riot isn't the best at communicating on some things though. They can't make "the rules of toxicity" too specific, because then they would have to just keep adding more and more specific rules while people find more and more ways to get around them ("don't be a jerk" is much simpler and gets things done a lot faster), but there are instances where even a bit of effective communication would go a long way.

I don't mean one player being reported on a regular basis, I mean the usage being reported. If a particular hypothetical phrase or word is reported every single time it is used by any player, then it's pretty safe to say that the vast majority of the community feels it is worthy of punishment. The more players reporting it that don't normally report indicates the community feels it is a more serious offense.

The result once the system has enough data to support action on that hypothetical word/phrase is that it is treated very harshly when it is brought to attention. It's words/phrases like this (the usual culprits like kys/racial slurs) that will get you banned very quickly, sometimes on the first offense, because the community has proven to the system that there isn't really a scenario where such things aren't offensive/toxic, and therefore it can action them very quickly. 

It doesn't have to leave wiggle room for banter like it does with simple swears.

Well, the Tristana wasn't (entirely) wrong, you can definitely get perma-banned from using "kys", though I wouldn't say it's "unjust".
